sections.section: This tutorial shows how different parts of an integration application can be split between different processes using Callable Flow nodes.  The example uses an Integration which provides a raw HTTP/JSON service. The data it receives needs to be routed to the correct file for processing by another business application.  The Integration also needs to keep an audit trail of all the requests received, regardless of where they were routed.
This example uses a Callable Flow to provide that audit service, so it can be invoked from one or more message flows, but is not exposed outside the Integration Bus environment.

The example can be run locally on the TESTNODE associated with the Integration Toolkit, and with some further configuration the same example can be used to show processing being split between different integration server processes, or even across different physical machines.

details.details: Open the HTTPInputMessageFlow, and click the Flow Exerciser icon to start recording the message path through the flow.
Click the Send Message icon to select a message to send to the flow.
Choose the ExampleInputMessage1, edit the message data if you like, and click Send. Your request message is sent to the HTTP input node.

sections.section: After the request message is processed, the message path is automatically highlighted on the message flow.

Click on any connection to see the data that passed through that connection. You can see that the request (input) message data has two fields named InputField1 and InputField2. The response (output) message has converted this to fields named OutputField1 and OutputField2.
